title: You can initialize auto-properties that have different visibility on their accessors. Here’s an example with a protected setter:

inline_content.Text: You can initialize auto-properties that have different visibility on their accessors. Here’s an example with a protected setter:

title: public string Name { get; protected set; } = "Cheeze";

content_resolved.code: public string Name { get; protected set; } = "Cheeze";

title: In addition to flexibility with visibility, you can also initialize read-only auto-properties. Here’s an example:

inline_content.Text: In addition to flexibility with visibility, you can also initialize read-only auto-properties. Here’s an example:

title:
public List<string> Ingredients { get; } = 
        new List<string> { "dough", "sauce", "cheese" };

content_resolved.code:
public List<string> Ingredients { get; } = 
        new List<string> { "dough", "sauce", "cheese" };

title: This example also shows how to initialize a property with a complex type. Also, auto-properties can’t be write-only, so that also precludes write-only initialization.

inline_content.Text: This example also shows how to initialize a property with a complex type. Also, auto-properties can’t be write-only, so that also precludes write-only initialization.

title: Initializers must evaluate to static expressions, just like field initializers. If you need to reference non-static members, you can either initialize properties in constructors like before, or use expression-bodied properties. Non-static expressions, like the one below (commented out), will generate a compiler error:

inline_content.Text: Initializers must evaluate to static expressions, just like field initializers. If you need to reference non-static members, you can either initialize properties in constructors like before, or use expression-bodied properties. Non-static expressions, like the one below (commented out), will generate a compiler error:

title: // public decimal X { get; set; } = InitMe();  // generates compiler error

content_resolved.code: // public decimal X { get; set; } = InitMe();  // generates compiler error

title: public short Type { get; private set; } = 15;

content_resolved.code: public short Type { get; private set; } = 15;
